Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I have said what I said and how people interpret that is a matter for themselves.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: In the circumstances I respectfully point out to the Chair that the normal follow up to that is that the Chair asks the Member concerned to withdraw.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I take it that the Minister did not reflect upon the professional integrity of Deputy O'Malley?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: My words stand for what I said and if Deputy O'Malley decides that those are reflecting upon his professional activities that is a matter for himself. I have said what I said and Deputy O'Malley's own words in this House are on the record to verify the accuracy of what I have said. He has already said in this House that he would not comply with the laws passed by this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: The Chair has asked the Minister for Finance to withdraw the remarks and the Minister has refused. The Chair, in my respectful submission, should now take the normal next step in the procedure, which is to ask the Member who has refused to withdraw remarks of this nature to withdraw from the House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am asking the Minister to help me in this dilemma. If the Minister did reflect upon the Deputy in the manner outlined would he kindly withdraw his remarks?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Deputy O'Malley has decided to interpret my remark in a certain way and that is a matter for him.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I take it that no such reflection was made on the Deputy?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I have said what I said and that stands.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): Does the Chair recall the actual words used by the Minister?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): That is what I suspected and I appreciate the Chair's difficulty.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Is it not true to say that the Minister is now disobeying the ruling of the Chair?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I take it that no reflection was intended?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Chair has stated that he does not recall the remarks and the Minister has refused to withdraw the remarks so I do not know how the Chair can arrive at that decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Not alone has the Minister refused to withdraw the remarks but he has endeavoured to amplify them or strengthen them if anything in subsequent remarks which he made. I should like to remind the Chair, with the greatest respect that he did ask the Minister to withdraw the remarks, properly so in my view. Not alone have the remarks not been withdrawn but they have been reiterated, not in so many words but, in effect, reiterated, more than once. In these circumstances the Chair's authority is openly and totally flouted. The Chair will have to have respect for its own position in this House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Chair is very conscious of its position in that regard. May I take it, Minister, no such reflection was intended?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: My words are on the record and it is the words that are on the record that matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: Is the Minister refusing to withdraw his remark?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: May I ask if the Minister would be good enough to withdraw any reflection made upon the Deputy in respect of his professional activities?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I have not made any reflection. I spoke the words which I stand over.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Therefore, no reflection was intended.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Chair asked the Minister to withdraw these remarks and he absolutely refused to do so. Deputy O'Malley is satisfied of the content of the remarks and of the allegation made by the Minister. The Minister is obviously taking a stand against the Chair and, with respect, I think the Chair should insist that the Minister withdraw or comply. Therefore, with respect, I think we must insist that he withdraw or comply with the normal procedure in this House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It seems to me no reflection of the kind to which the Deputy refers was intended.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): I can appreciate your position, a Cheann Chomhairle. You cannot be expected to hear every word that passes to and fro in this House, but if you heard the exact words the Minister said, I think you would take a different view.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Irrespective of the view the Chair might take, could I submit to the Chair that it has already formally requested the Minister twice to withdraw the remark concerned? The Minister has specifically refused twice. The Chair's authority is being openly flouted by the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The intimation I received back from the Minister was that no such reflection was intended.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: He did not say that. He went out of his way not to say that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I put it to the Minister that no such reflection was intended. Is that the position?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: There is your answer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: With respect, Sir, the record speaks for itself. I have already answered your request to me and Deputy O'Malley's interpretation of what I said. What Deputy O'Malley's interpretation is is a matter for himself. My words speak for themselves.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: May I submit——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Let us get on with the business of the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: No, Sir. Your authority is being usurped here.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Yes, by the Minister for Finance. The dignity of the House demands that he be treated as he deserves to be treated for openly flouting your ruling and your request to him.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy may not exaggerate the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: You have asked him on three occasions to withdraw his comments and he has absolutely refused to do so. In a situation such as this the Minister is obliged to observe the rules of the House the same as any other Member. I sympathise with your position and deplore that the Minister for Finance should openly defy you in this manner. It is a reflection on himself, and it indicates the manner in which he has treated this House on so many occasions. I regret that he should now treat the Chair in this manner, and while I sympathise with you, I feel you must do your duty in regard to the Minister for Finance.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I heard the Minister's remark. Apart from the discourtesy to the Chair, the Minister made a remark which was capable of a certain interpretation. If he made that remark outside this House and did not accept the invitation to disclaim that it referred to Deputy O'Malley in his professional capacity Deputy O'Malley would have an action against him, actionable per se, for defamation. The Minister, therefore, apart from being discourteous to the Chair, is cowardly enough to hide behind the privilege of this House to make such an accusation which he as a lawyer knows would be actionable per se if he made it outside this House. I invite the Minister to repeat, for Deputy O'Malley's benefit, that remark outside the House and then Deputy O'Malley would have his remedy or else the Minister would have to disclaim his intention and the construction that has been put on his words.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I entirely repudiate what Deputy de Valera has said.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: Does the Minister repudiate that it refers to Deputy O'Malley in that category, because if it does, it would be actionable per se outside this House?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I am not going to be engaged here in a cross-examination situation.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: The Minister is hiding behind privilege.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I am not hiding behind privilege, and I am certainly not a coward.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: The Minister is hiding behind the privilege of this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I am not doing either. I have asserted myself quite openly. How people choose to interpret that is a matter for themselves. I do not see why the Chair should be embarrassed into a situation because some people act in accordance with their own inclinations to put a mischievous interpretation on everything.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: The Minister had an opportunity of a simple disclaimer of that intention.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Let us continue with the business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: On a point of order. Could the Minister be asked to stand while addressing this House?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Let us get back to the amendment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: I cannot let this matter stand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: The Deputy is a politician, not a lawyer. Talk about legal humbug.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: This is a matter of the most extreme seriousness to me. What Deputy de Valera has said is right. If this remark was passed outside this House I had an action for defamation which was actionable per se without proof of any special damage. It is one of a category of five actions because it refers to my professional career. Because any words uttered in this House are privileged the tradition has been always that if any remark of that nature was made an apology would be made and the remark withdrawn because it is not possible to sue on it. The Chair has twice asked the Minister for Finance to withdraw the remark in question. The Minister has not alone refused to withdraw it but has added insult to injury by his attitude and by his remarks. I do not want to have to make this suggestion, but I think that some people will think in this House and outside it that if those remarks had been made by a backbencher or by someone other than a Minister the Chair would have insisted that a repeated request for withdrawal of these remarks would have been seen through, either by the remarks being withdrawn or by the Member concerned being asked to leave the House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Chair's earliest comments were that the remarks were a political charge, and it was the Deputy's own construction that the Chair sought to clarify.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: The Chair also stated that it did not hear the remark, so I find it difficult to see how the Chair could have come to the conclusion that the remarks concerned were a political charge.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The remarks in general.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: In general? I was at pains to point out that for ten minutes it was vulgar political abuse of the lowest kind, but the very last sentence was a different matter.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Could we please get on with the business before us?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: If the Chair would assert its authority and do in relation to the Minister for Finance what it would do in relation to any other Deputy. I know it is very unusual for the Chair to be faced with this problem with a Minister, but nonetheless he is a Member of this House and he is as amenable to the discipline of this House and as subject to the rulings of the Chair as any other Member. The fact that he is a Minister should not and, in my submission, cannot be allowed to enable him to get away with what has happened when a backbencher would not get away with it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: I think we have seen a classic example in relation to the Fianna Fáil reaction——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): The Deputy was not in the House. What is he talking about?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: I am fully aware of what happened.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: Did the Deputy hear the remarks?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: We see a classic example of lawyers on the Opposition benches, well briefed by taxation experts, well briefed by a very select group of advisers——

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: There is one on the Deputy's right.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): Deputy Desmond is pursuing a different debate altogether.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: We have seen lawyers coming into this House who seem to be acting——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: On a point of order. Is Deputy Desmond in order? Are his remarks relevant to the problem before the House?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am asking that we get back to the business before us. May I take it from the Minister that no personal charge was intended against Deputy O'Malley?

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: In regard to his profession.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: With all due respect, what matters are the words which were uttered. The words which I uttered stand here. Any interpretation put upon those words by others is a matter for themselves but not, I would say with all respect, a matter for interpretation by the Chair as a consequence of a declaration by others as to what they understood the words to mean.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: May I take it that no personal reflection was intended then?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I think the words speak for themselves.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am taking it that no personal reflection was intended.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Once again the Minister has refused. The Chair has asked four or five times and each time the Minister has refused.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: No personal reflection was intended.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: No, Sir, he refuses. You have asked him four or five times and he refuses to say it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: The Deputy said that he would not obey the law if it was passed in relation to the disclosure of a client's information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Could we get back to the matter in hand, Sir? This Deputy was sent in to disrupt and interrupt in the hope that in the course of a row the whole thing would be glossed over. I am sorry that this is the cause of trouble to the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am taking the view that no personal reflection was intended.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: You asked the Minister that four or five times and he resolutely refused each time to tell you that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Would the Minister please help me to proceed with the business of the House by intimating that this is the position?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I think the Chair gave its understanding of the remarks when they were first uttered. Since then there has been a succession of allegations made from Opposition benches as to what the words meant. The Chair's interpretation is a valid interpretation. That is the one that was first given by the Chair and it is obviously the only interpretation that matters no matter how sensitive other Deputies may be.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am ruling positively that the remarks made were a political charge and that no personal reflection was intended and I am going on that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: The Chair has already told the House that he did not hear the remarks. How then can he rule?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Chair did not say that. I heard the Minister's speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: But you already told the House you did not hear the remarks——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Chair did not say that. The Deputies opposite seem to have forgotten that the Chair changed over two years ago.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: And got a kick in the groin which he deserved.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: On your own words, Sir——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am going on to the next business, Deputy Colley's amendment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I submit that you have in the last few minutes ruled on something you had no right to rule on—you did not hear it.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy will resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I will resume my seat but I am not going to be cowed by the arrogance and intransigence of those in the front benches on the opposite side——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Deputy Fitzgerald, I have ruled——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I sympathise with you, Sir, that the Minister should disrespect you in such a way.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: May I put the amendment in the name of Deputy Colley?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: No Sir.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): I think if the Chair had heard the words of the Minister——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We must get away from this matter and deal with the business before us.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): But Deputies have already spoken in regard to this matter. I think very few actually heard the words. I must say that the Chair did not exactly hear the words which the Minister uttered against Deputy O'Malley. I have them written down —exactly what they are—and I am sure if the Chair knew them he would make a different ruling against the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We must get on with the business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: May I come in again and recollect the sequence of events?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: No. We have dwelt for some time on this matter. It would serve no purpose to continue. I want to get back to the amendment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Chair also tried——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I appeal to the Deputy to obey the Chair; otherwise I shall have to deal with the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: You ought to deal with the Minister. You are afraid to deal with the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I will be the scapegoat but you are afraid to deal with the Minister. If that is justice it is time something was done about order in this House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Will the Deputy please allow business to proceed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I will obey you any time Sir, and I sympathise with you for the way the Minister ignored your please to him and I also sympathise with you——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The amendment please, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: You asked him to withdraw and you asked him to help you. He commented and he reiterated what he already said but he made no effort to help you despite your pleas.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Will the Deputy help me by getting back to the business of the House?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: No, Sir, not until such time as the Minister either withdraws or intimates that he will withdraw the words he mentioned already.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Deputy Colley's amendment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: No, Sir.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: The Minister is preparing an apology.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am putting the question that the amendment be made.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: No, Sir, hold on.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: On another point. I was listening to the exchange and on two occasions I heard the Minister mention in a derogatory fashion the name of a person who was not in the House. I was rather surprised that the Chair did not draw his attention to this in that he was insulting a former Deputy who could not be here to defend himself. I thought it was traditional for the Chair to draw a Member's attention to an attack on somebody——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is speaking on another matter altogether.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: But was he entitled to make derogatory remarks about the former Deputy MacEntee when Mr. MacEntee had no opportunity——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Chair is anxious to make some progress with the business before us.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: I also am anxious to make progress but I understood——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Deputy Colley's amendment, No. 2b.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: No way—not like that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: We want to make progress and we want to help you but we feel that the manner in which you have been treated tonight by the Minister for Finance is absolutely disgraceful. He has ignored your plea to him in addition to ignoring——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have ruled that the charge was a political charge and that no personal reflection was intended.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: What can you rule, Sir?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have ruled, Deputy.
(Interruptions.)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: In view of the problem and the attitude of the Minister and in view of the fact that we have only some 50 minutes left, would the Chair consider adjourning the House for the remainder of the sitting in order to prevent any unseemly scenes as a result of the attitude of the Minister?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: No, I think we should proceed with the business before us.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: The Deputy is very self-righteous for such a young man.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The amendment in the name of Deputy Colley.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: May I ask you to reconsider your ruling?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have ruled and that is that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: It would not be the first one you changed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: You did say earlier, Sir, that you did not hear the words. Following that you turned to the Minister—we are well aware of the Minister's calibre——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Please, Deputy. I am not going to adjourn the House——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Adjourn the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: You pleaded with him, Sir, and he continued to ignore your pleas. In that situation you had an option open to you.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy must allow the business to proceed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: We will certainly co-operate in every way if the Minister will either withdraw his remarks or apologise to Deputy O'Malley. This is a simple situation. This Minister cannot be allowed to say what he likes.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have ruled on the matter and what is now before us is amendment No. 2b.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: No, Sir.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Amendment No. 2b.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: I am aware that you are not familiar, Sir, with what has been going on for the past 15 or 20 minutes.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: I am aware of the fact that the Chair has ruled in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Chair's ruling was wrong and if he was man enough he should stay here.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair has ruled on the matter and that is that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: In other words, if one of us persists he will get the treatment that should have been given to the arrogant Minister for Finance who apparently is entitled in this House to say what he likes about whom he likes. There is one law for the Minister for Finance——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Now, Deputy Fitzgerald——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I know I will get the treatment that should have been meted out to the Minister. If this is the kind of order that prevails in this House it is time——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Will the Deputy allow the Minister to proceed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Not until there is an apology from him for behaving in the way he did.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Deputies must not shout at the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: My microphone has been switched off. The Chair may not be able to hear me.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair can hear quite well.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I apologise for the shouting. It was not intentional. The Ceann Comhairle was faced with——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Ceann Comhairle has made a ruling and the tradition in this House is that in that case the ruling is accepted by Deputies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Is it not accepted, also, that when a Member of the House is asked to withdraw a remark as the Minister for Finance was asked to do on two occasions tonight by the Ceann Comhairle, either the request is complied with or the Member concerned leaves the House? Twice the Ceann Comhairle asked that a certain remark be withdrawn and twice the Minister refused to comply with the request.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy has enough experience to know that the Chair cannot go back on what has been ruled on.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: I have plenty of experience of Members being asked to withdraw remarks, refusing to do so and then being asked to leave the House.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The subject-matter of what has been ruled on is being re-opened.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the Chair say whether the Minister complied with the request of the Ceann Comhairle to withdraw the remark?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: This matter has been ruled on by the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: That is not the point. I want to know whether the Minister complied with the request to withdraw the remark he made about Deputy O'Malley.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy is well aware that the Chair is not questioned on matters like this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I want to know whether the Minister for Finance did as he was told by the Chair?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: I am sure the Deputy was present when the Chair was making a decision on this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: This is evading the question I am putting to you, that is, whether the request to the Minister to withdraw the remark about Deputy O'Malley was complied with.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy will resume his seat. The Leas-Cheann Comhairle does not review the rulings of the Ceann Comhairle.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I am talking about the direction given to the Minister for Finance by the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy is saying that he wishes the Leas-Cheann Comhairle to review a ruling given already.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I am asking whether the request was complied with and if not what you intend doing about it.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair would like to proceed with the business of the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: First, you must clear up the mess that has been created by the Minister in ignoring the request of the Ceann Comhairle.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy must allow business to proceed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Do you intend answering my question?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair will not be questioned by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I suppose you must endeavour to whitewash the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moore Mr. Moore
Speaker.P: Deputy O'Malley has been slandered here this evening. I put it to the Chair that he asked the Minister to withdraw the remark concerned both in the interest of Deputy O'Malley's character and in the interest of the House. I cannot see why the Minister cannot do this. If a Member has been injured in any way we must try to repair the injury and the Minister is the only person who can repair the injury in this case.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Amendment No. 2 (b).

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I sympathise with you, Sir, as I sympathised with the Ceann Comhairle. I shall not argue but would point out that before you came in the Ceann Comhairle was placed in a very embarrassing position because of the actions of the Minister who sat and defied the Chair and refused on two occasions to comply with the request made.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy is going over a matter that has been dealt with already.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I am merely endeavouring to appraise you of what has gone on.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair does not want to know.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Chair has a duty to be fair and to protect the rights of Members.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair protects the rights of all Members in so far as he can.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Then, protect the rights of Deputy O'Malley.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: We appreciate fully the difficult situation in which you have been placed in coming in at this stage but the Minister has defied the pleadings of the Ceann Comhairle.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: There is no point in going back over that argument with the Leas-Cheann Comhairle at this stage. He does not review the ruling of the Ceann Comhairle. That is a standing rule of this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Chair will appreciate, being the just and fair man he is, that comments and remarks have been made against a Deputy on this side of the House by a Minister who defied the Chair and refused a request to withdraw the remark concerned. On two occasions the Chair pleaded with the Minister to help the Chair out of the dilemma but the Minister was immovable in the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Then, the Ceann Comhairle ran away.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Allegations should not be made against the Ceann Comhairle.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Nor against any Member of this House.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair realises that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: Would the Chair consider adjourning the House until he has had the opportunity of studying the unrevised version of what the Minister said so as to ascertain how guilty the Minister is in this regard?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Ceann Comhairle's ruling was that the business of the House should proceed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: This is a very unfortunate situation. As one of the people in this House who detests seeing the business being interrupted for any reason, might I say that I was listening on the inter-com to the remarks made by the Minister and there is no question but that such a remark should be withdrawn. I have been here for almost 20 years. During that time I have had experience of various persons in the Chair but never have I known a Member, be he a Minister or otherwise, being asked to withdraw something, being appealed to to withdraw a remark by the Chair but not doing so and continuing to remain in the House. If it were my case or, indeed, the case of any other Deputy here. I would have no hesitation in withdrawing the relevant remark. The Ceann Comhairle begged repeatedly of the Minister to withdraw the remark.
If the Minister were a man at all he would withdraw the remark at this stage. It is easy to verify what is said. I suggest that the unrevised Official Report be sent for.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Send for the Report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: In this way the Chair can verify what is on the record but not without it. The Ceann Comhairle was placed in an awful dilemma but the Minister would not comply with the request to withdraw the remark and we now have the business of the House being held up. Surely, Deputy O'Malley's reputation stands for something here and must be upheld. Is it not the duty of the Chair to uphold the reputation of any Member? Had we been outside the Chamber when the remark was made, Deputy O'Malley could seek redress quickly. Perhaps in those circumstances he would take the law into his own hands as I would if such remarks were made about me. I appeal to the Chair to adjourn the House until after he has perused the Report and made up his mind as to whether the remark should be withdrawn. The whole situation is unfair to the Chair, to the House and, in particular, to Deputy O'Malley.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair can only proceed on the ruling that has been given in regard to the matter and ask that Members proceed with the business before the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: May I point out to the Leas-Cheann Comhairle who was not present when this affair took place that on two occasions in the course of the debate following the defamatory remark of the Minister, the Chair appealed to the Minister to withdraw the remark on the ground that it was improper and should be withdrawn.

Subsequently as a result of advice apparently received about ten minutes later, the Chair purported to rule that the charge concerned was a political charge, that the defamation concerned was in the form of a political charge. I would respectfully remind the Leas-Cheann Comhairle that that ruling is totally inconsistent with the repeated request of the Chair for the withdrawal of the remark, because if the remark were a political charge, the Chair could not have asked the Minister to withdraw it. Nonetheless, the Chair asked him specifically on two occasions to withdraw it and on each occasion he refused, and on four or five other occasions, the Chair asked the Minister if he would say that it did not have any personal imputations, or some words to that effect and again the Minister refused to do so, but specifically he was asked twice to withdraw the remark. He could not have been asked if the remark was in the nature of a political charge.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I consider, without any disrespect to yourself, Sir, that many of the comments of the past 20 minutes have not been in order but as seemingly, they have been permitted, I want to say this. you have heard a jaundiced account. The Chair asked if the words uttered by me had the meaning attributed to them by Deputy O'Malley would I withdraw them, to which I replied that the words stood, that they were on the record and that I was not going to answer charges as to what the meaning of those words was. That is the reality and the truth of the situation. I suggest now that as the Fianna Fáil Party have resolved by every and many means to obstruct the wealth tax and having gained nearly 35 minutes by this form of obstruction, they should now try to get back to a discussion on the merits or demerits of the Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: When you decide to withdraw or apologise to Deputy O'Malley for what you said, there will be no problem.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: The Minister is now qualifying for the top role in the television sponger advert.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Further to what the Minister said, he was asked on two occasions——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy is going back on the discussion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Specifically the Minister was asked on two occasions by the Ceann Comhairle to withdraw and he refused to do so, and normally the procedure then would have continued and the Minister would not now be sitting in the House. We must realise that if one of us were in that position and refused as the Minister did, he would not be sitting here, and rightly so, if we continued to refuse the request of the Chair. The Chair went further and pleaded with the Minister to help him out of his dilemma and that was the word he used, but the Minister in typical arrogant fashion, with the attitude of the spoiled child which he has always adopted in the House, and of course being stubborn, refused to yield an inch.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy is making an argument which he has already made and to which the Chair has listened.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Nothing has come from the argument.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: There is no point in talking about it unless you do something about it. Adjourn the House until the records are seen and checked.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Can we have the records?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: All we have to do is to check the record and see and then we can accept the ruling of the Leas-Cheann Comhairle or the Ceann Comhairle, without disorder.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Ceann Comhairle has already ruled.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: The Chair asked the Minister to apologise and he did not do so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: That is the kernel of the whole thing. The Ceann Comhairle should not have made a decision and then run out, leaving you holding the baby.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: If the Minister takes 35 minutes to learn manners, he loses 35 minutes, but he need not blame us.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: It is not in the interest of anybody that the House should be brought into any form of disrepute. On a point of information, might I ask you, Sir, to read for the House the relevant Standing Order in relation to a decision of the Chair, of a Member asking or requesting and even pleading which the Chair ought not to be seen to do. Would he read the relevant Standing Order as regards procedure——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair does not read Standing Orders.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Can the Chair advise me what the particular Standing Order is in these circumstances?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair has already given an answer. The Leas-Cheann Comhairle does not review rulings of the Ceann Comhairle.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: I am sure you do not wish to see this House brought into any form of disorder, but nevertheless allegations have been made and a wild statement made, and the Ceann Comhairle asked that these statements be withdrawn.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair deprecates the facts at all stages, and always has, that this House should be brought into disrepute at any stage. That is why the Chair has been appealing to Deputies to proceed with the business of the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: And Ministers.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Everybody—Ministers and Deputies—they are all the same as far as the Chair is concerned. With no exception, anybody on any side of the House should obey the rules of the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: In the interests of order and decorum, the Minister should obey the decision of the Chair or depart. We wish to see order and continuity in this House but there is nevertheless a set procedure which I would ask you to invoke and let it be clearly seen that there is one law that governs from your Chair.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: There is only one law as far as the Chair is concerned and the Chair at the moment is carrying out that, and I have quoted it. The Leas-Cheann Comhairle does not review the rulings of the Ceann Comhairle.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lalor Mr. Lalor
Speaker.P: We had the position that the Ceann Comhairle asked the Minister to withdraw his remark and the Minister refused.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: This is a very particular case and the Chair ought to adjourn the House until we have had the benefit of the record and the appeal to the Minister to withdraw.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair has quoted the relevant guiding line which the Chair is following at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: Could I repeat my plea? I have been here for 20 years and it is the first time I have ever seen a request of the Chair being disobeyed and the person who disobeyed that request getting away with it. The Minister was asked on numerous occasions—certainly three or four—to withdraw the remark he made and he refused to do so and he has not been asked to leave the House. In these circumstances——

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: Would the Chair look at the record?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: In these circumstances, I would plead with you, Sir, to adjourn the House until tomorrow morning, that you get together with the Ceann Comhairle and have a look at what is on the record, at what the Minister really did say and what we all heard him say and at that stage make up your own minds as to what the Minister is going to do about it. The Ceann Comhairle has asked the Minister on a number of occasions to withdraw the remark.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Chair has listened to what has been said on either side and the Chair has quoted from long experience in this House that the Leas-Cheann Comhairle does not review the rulings of the Ceann Comhairle. At the present moment it seems to the Chair that it cannot get from either side of the House the kind of co-operation which would enable the business of the House to proceed. This is addressed to the Minister and to Deputies on the Government side as much as to Deputies on the Opposition side. In these circumstances, the Chair is now deciding to adjourn the House.
The Dáil adjourned at 10 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Friday, 6th June, 1975.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kerry Haulage Licence.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Byrne Dr. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Transport and Power why a person in County Kerry (name supplied) has been refused a haulage licence in view of the fact that public transport provided by CIE cannot meet the demand in this area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport and Power (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport and Power (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: Under section 115 of the Transport Act, 1944, I may extend the operation of any merchandise (existing carrier's) licence or grant a merchandise licence to any person if it appears to me that the existing merchandise road transport facilities in any area are inadequate.

MainHeading.P: In the case the Deputy has in mind I have received representations to the effect that CIE cannot meet the demand in the area but only one case of a specific shortcoming on the part of CIE has been established. CIE have offered on a number of occasions to meet the parties concerned to discuss their transport needs but the offer has not been taken up nor have the parties called on CIE transport for a considerable time. Apart from CIE the area is served by a number of licensed hauliers. I am not satisfied, therefore, that there is an inadequacy of merchandise road transport facilities in the area.
